data.text: SPD Shoes That's Comfortable for Walking
Does anyone have any recommendations on an SPD shoe that's also comfortable/casual enough for walking around while touring? TIA...

It's really going to be a personal preference thing here- go to a shop and try a whole bunch of them on. They make SPD shoes that look like hiking shoes but I find they're waaaay to stuffy for hard riding, my feet get swampy in them, I don't use the style anymore. I own a pretty big collection of cycling shoes (from like $80 to $400), and honestly the most comfortable are the ~$100-150 sporty ones. Velcro straps wear out quickly and aren't replaceable but they're easy to tighten *just right*. I also like boa-style mechanisms and I'm glad to see them on less expensive shoes these days.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: Shimano SPD sandals would be an option then... when it rains get out the goretex oversox.

data.text: Braden the velcro comment is inaccurate and depends on the overall durability of the shoe

data.text: I always use a winter boot (all year round) MTB spd type. Fully waterproof and flexyish for around camp yeah they can get a little warm but with a quality merino sock it's not that bad. Nothing worse than soaking wet cold feet for me but we get plenty of rain here in the uk. Current shoe is the Northwave Raptor Artic Gtx.

data.text: Iâ€™ve recently purchased the Shimano MT3 Touring and they are comfortable on and off the bike.
data.author: Ian Hinchliffe

data.text: As above, head to a store and try some out. These days there are versions that are basically runners/trainers, sandals, and of course those with a stiffer sole. I have some Mavic ones that are pretty tolerable off bike, if just pottering around, but stiff enough that they don't defeat the purpose of cycling specific shoes.
data.author: Simon Tomkins

data.text: SPD on a mountain bike shoe doesnâ€™t slip on pavement or gravel when walking and is more flexible than a road shoe. We ride mostly in warm weather so I look for a mesh forefoot area. I am not a fan of the BOA laces because you have to yank that wire quite hard to get the shoe open enough to get them on and off. I wear Shimano sandals with SPD cleats for touring because if it rains or is muddy a quick rinse and they are ready for the next day. They are also comfortable for walking around but they can be a bit loose in the forefoot area which makes it more of a twist to disengage from the cleat. They only make the sandals in unisex sizes which seems too wide the the forefoot area for a womanâ€™s foot.
data.author: Mary Ann Latzgo Padglick
